Lars Clausen writes:
> Now try doing that with tens or hundreds of terabytes.  10TB would take
> 280000 seconds, or over three days.  Most of that will be spent reading
> data that is not used and should be skippable.

Yes. Once the index is built, however, you will not need to build it
again, hopefully.

>  Did you in your test make sure the file wasn't in memory?
[...]

libarc memory maps the contents of the arc files: it relies on the OS
to page the file as necessary. I did this intentionally to avoid
having to read the entire file, and to avoid the added complexity of
managing multiple buffer reads while running the inflation code.

> The ARC format was particularly designed so that you did not ever have
> to go through all the files, you could just read the metadata lines and
> skip the bodies to make the index, then use the index to get the entries
> you want.  That's a not insignificant part of what makes it effective.

If you build a CDX file from the compressed contents, you have the
offsets in the compressed file (V field) allowing you to decompress
the entry you are interested in.

> > > Of course, the proposed idea of having the metadata
> > 
> > The more I thought about your idea on my drive into the office this
> > morning, the more I like it. Keep the URL record uncompressed, and
> > include a compression method and offset to the start of the next
> > entry.
> 
> You'd lose the zmore/zless usability bit, though.  I'm not sure which
> I'd prefer.

Yes.

> > You can't go into the middle of an uncompressed ARC file and easily

> 
> /^http:\/\/[^ ]* [0-9]+\.[0-9]+\.[0-9]+\.[0-9]+/ is nigh foolproof.  

Touche, if your regexp engine allows forwards and backwards searches.

> > It also depends on the tools. With libarc working with index-less

>

Of course.
